case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Keshavji Morarji

facts.text: The case is a reference under section 66 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 before the High Court of Judicature at Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: In a reference under section 66 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, the High Court of Judicature at Bombay answered the second question set out herein below in the negative,

facts.text: High Court answered the second question in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: answered the second question set out herein below in the negative, and declined to answer the first question

facts.text: High Court declined to answer the first question.

anchor.surface_text: and declined to answer the first question Whether, on the facts of the case, the provisions of section 16 3  a  iv  are applicable to the two trusts

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax appealed to Supreme Court with special leave.

anchor.surface_text: With special leave, the Commissioner of Income-tax has appealed to this companyrt.

facts.text: Keshavji is a resident of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: Keshavji, a resident of Bombay, has a son, Jaysinh, and three daughters, Indumati, Kusum and Dipika,

facts.text: Keshavji has a son Jaysinh and three daughters Indumati, Kusum and Dipika.

anchor.surface_text: Keshavji, a resident of Bombay, has a son, Jaysinh, and three daughters, Indumati, Kusum and Dipika, of whom, in the relevant years of assessment,

facts.text: Dipika was a minor in the relevant years of assessment.

anchor.surface_text: Indumati, Kusum and Dipika, of whom, in the relevant years of assessment, Dipika was a minor.

facts.text: Jaysinh has two infant children Bipin and Kamla.

anchor.surface_text: Jaysinh has two infant children, Bipin and Kamla.

facts.text: On June 14, 1952, Keshavji transferred Rs. 5 lakhs to Jaysinh.

anchor.surface_text: On Junde 14, 1952, Keshavji transferred a sum of Rs. 5 lakhs to his son, Jaysinh.

facts.text: On February 22, 1954, Keshavji settled Rs. 4,41,000 in favour of minor grandchildren Bipin and Kamla by deed.

anchor.surface_text: On February 22, 1954, by a deed, Keshavji settled a sum of Rs. 4,41,000 in favour of his minor grand-children, Bipin and Kamla,

facts.text: On February 22, 1954, Jaysinh settled Rs. 1,54,000 upon sisters Indumati, Kusum and Dipika by deed.

anchor.surface_text: and on the same day Jaysinh, by another deed, settled a sum of Rs. 1,54,000 upon his three sisters, Indumati, Kusum and Dipika.

facts.text: Proceedings for assessment for years 1955-56 and 1956-57.

anchor.surface_text: In proceedings for assessment of tax for the assessment years 1955-56 and 1956-57 the Income-tax Officer held

facts.text: Income-tax Officer held that Keshavji indirectly transferred assets to his minor daughter Dipika under section 16(3)(a)(iv).

anchor.surface_text: the Income-tax Officer held that Keshavji had by the settlement indirectly transferred assets belonging to him to his minor daughter and Jaysinh had transferred assets belonging to him to his minor children,

facts.text: Income-tax Officer directed income attributable to Dipika's share assessed in Keshavji's hands and Jaysinh's trust income in his hands under section 16(3)(a)(iv).

anchor.surface_text: and on that view directed that under section 16 3  a  iv  the income attributable to the share of Dipika be assessed in the hands of Keshavji and the income from the trust created by Jaysinh being in reality for the benefit of his minor children be assessed in his hands.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld ITO's view on nature of transactions.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld the view of the Income-tax Officer about the nature of the transactions.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner held only income related to minors' interest included, not whole assets.

anchor.surface_text: He, however, held that the income which companyld be included in the total income of the assessee was only that amount which related to the interest in the assets companyveyed in favour of the minors and number the income of the whole of the assets.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal confirmed Appellate Assistant Commissioner's order.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal companyfirmed the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: High Court held simultaneous deeds do not justify inference of indirect transfers under section 16(3)(a)(iv).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the circumstance that the two deeds of settlement were executed on the same day did number justify an inference that Keshavji and Jaysinh made indirect transfers of assets

facts.text: Tribunal found gifts mutually prompted and each provided consideration for the other, constituting indirect transfers.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal in recording its companyclusion has observed The gifts by the father and son on February 22, 1954, have been mutually prompted so that it is impossible to escape the companyclusion that each of the so-called gifts had provided the companysideration for the other.

facts.text: Both settlors Keshavji and Jaysinh were residing in the same house as per description in deeds.

anchor.surface_text: that from the description given in the two deeds of settlement both the settlors were residing in the same house

facts.text: No explanation given why Keshavji and Jaysinh executed deeds simultaneously.

anchor.surface_text: that numberexplanation was given why Keshavji and his son, Jaysinh, executed the two deeds of settlement simultaneously.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal and remanded the case to High Court to call for supplementary statement from Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: We allow this appeal. We direct that the case be remanded with the direction that the High Court do call upon the Tribunal to submit a statement of the case under section 66 4  of the Indian Income-tax Act in the light of the tests expounded by this companyrt in Commissioner of Income-tax v. C. M. Kothari
section 66 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, the High Court of Judicature at Bombay answered the second question set out herein below in the negative,
Whether, on the facts of the case, the provisions of section 16 3  a  iv  are applicable to the two trusts created by Keshavji Morarji and Jaysinh Keshavji both on February 22, 1954 ?

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the section says that the assets must be those of the husband, but it does not mean that the same assets should reach the wife. It may be that the assets, in the course of being transferred, may be changed deliberately into assets of a like value of another person A chain of transfers, if not comprehended by the word indirectly, would easily defeat the object of the law which is to tax the income of the wife in the hands of the husband, if the income of the wife arises to her from assets transferred by the husband

concepts.interpretation: Transfers fall within section if inter-connected, parts of same transaction, circuitous method adopted as device to evade section; no need for technical consideration; chain transfers included

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: transfers by the son to the mother and by the father-in-law to his daughter-in-law were made as companysideration for each other. We do number agree.

concepts.unlisted_description: Multi-factor test for determining indirect transfers under IT Act s16(3)(a): interconnection, same transaction, evasion device

anchor.surface_text: the observations made by the Madras High Court in L. G. Balakrishnan v. Commissioner of Income-tax on which reliance was placed at the Bar that if cross-transactions are independent of each other the section cannot have any application. Even if they are parts of the same transaction they would fall outside the section if they are real. But if they are nothing more than mere appearances devised to circumvent the section assiduously maintained, the department can lift the veil and declare the true nature of the transaction as being one within the section - do not correctly interpret section 16 3  a , clauses  iii  and  iv .

issues.text: Whether, on the facts of the case, the provisions of section 16 3  a  iv  are applicable to the two trusts created by Keshavji Morarji and Jaysinh Keshavji both on February 22, 1954 ?

anchor.surface_text: Whether, on the facts of the case, the provisions of section 16 3  a  iv  are applicable to the two trusts created by Keshavji Morarji and Jaysinh Keshavji both on February 22, 1954 ?

arguments.claim: Gifts by father and son mutually prompted, each provided consideration for the other, constitutes indirect transfer to minor children

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal in recording its conclusion has observed The gifts by the father and son on February 22, 1954, have been mutually prompted so that it is impossible to escape the conclusion that each of the so-called gifts had provided the consideration for the other. It cannot be denied that the minor children of each of the two assessees have received benefit to the extent of at least Rs. 1,54,000

arguments.court_reasoning: Observations cryptic, did not refer to all material evidence or apply proper test

arguments.claim: Simultaneous deeds and cross-gifts do not establish mutual consideration or indirect transfers under section 16(3)(a)(iv)

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the circumstance that the two deeds of settlement were executed on the same day did not justify an inference that Keshavji and Jaysinh made indirect transfers of assets in favour of their respective children for the purposes of section 16 3  a  iv  of the Act. Citing with apparent approval the decision of the Madras High Court in C. M. Kothari v. Commissioner of Income-tax, the High Court held that the fact that there were cross-gifts either by itself or taken with the fact that the gifts were simultaneous in point of time did not establish that each transfer formed consideration for the other or that the transfers were mutual.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the same assets should reach the wife. It may be that the assets, in the companyrse of being transferred, may be changed deliberately into assets of

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court observations not accurate, ignored other circumstances and material evidence

arguments.claim: High Court erred in advisory jurisdiction by upsetting Tribunal's findings of fact and relying on Madras High Court decision in C.M. Kothari which was reversed by Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal, counsel for the Commissioner submitted that the learned judges of the High Court in exercising their advisory jurisdiction upset findings of fact recorded by the Tribunal and persuaded themselves to record an answer in the negative on the second question relying mainly on the decision of the Madras High Court in C. M. Kotharis case, which has since been reversed by this court in Commissioner of Income-tax v. C. M. Kothari.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: d. To mention only a few the two settlors were related as father and son that the father had made a settlement in favour of his grand-children simulta

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed High Court improperly upset facts and did not apply correct test

arguments.claim: Several circumstances support contention of indirect transfer beyond mere simultaneity: father-son relation, simultaneous settlements involving minor, same house, no explanation for simultaneity

anchor.surface_text: There were several other circumstances which appeared from the order of the Tribunal which are incorporated in the statement of case and the record. To mention only a few the two settlors were related as father and son that the father had made a settlement in favour of his grand-children simultaneously with the execution of a deed of settlement by the son in favour of his sisters one of whom was a minor that from the description given in the two deeds of settlement both the settlors were residing in the same house that no explanation was given why Keshavji and his son, Jaysinh, executed the two deeds of settlement simultaneously.

arguments.claim: Under section 16(3)(a)(iii), indirect transfers include chain transfers that are interconnected parts of same transaction adopted as device to evade section, without need for technical consideration

anchor.surface_text: In a recent judgment of this court, in Commissioner of Income-tax v. C. M. Kothari this court, in dealing with a case under section 16 3  a  iii  of the Income-tax Act, observed at page 110 It is true that the section says that the assets must be those of the husband, but it does not mean that the same assets should reach the wife. It may be that the assets, in the course of being transferred, may be changed deliberately into assets of a like value of another person A chain of transfers, if not comprehended by the word indirectly, would easily defeat the object of the law which is to tax the income of the wife in the hands of the husband, if the income of the wife arises to her from assets transferred by the husband It is next contended that even if chain transactions be included, then, unless there is consideration for the transfer by the husband, each transfer must be regarded as independent, and in the present case, the department has not proved that the transfers by the son to the mother and by the father-in-law to his daughter-in-law were made as consideration for each other. We do not agree. It is not necessary that there should be consideration in the technical sense. If the two transfers are inter-connected and are parts of the same transaction in such a way that it can be said that the circuitous method has been adopted as a device to evade implications of this section, the case will fall within the section.

arguments.claim: Same considerations relevant for section 16(3)(a)(iv) as for section 16(3)(a)(iii)

anchor.surface_text: In C. M. Kotharis case the court was interpreting section 16 3  a  iii , but the same considerations are relevant in the application of section 16 3  a  iv .

arguments.claim: Tribunal and High Court did not examine evidence in light of correct test of interconnection and evasion device

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal merely observed that the two transactions were mutually prompted and each of the gifts provided for the consideration of the other and did not attempt an examination of the evidence in the light of the true test. The High Court, in disagreeing with the Tribunal, also did not consider all the material evidence in the light of the test suggested by this court.

arguments.claim: Observations in L.G. Balakrishnan v. Commissioner of Income-tax do not correctly interpret section 16(3)(a) clauses (iii) and (iv); focus is on whether transfers part of same transaction to evade section, not on unreality or appearance

anchor.surface_text: We may observe, lest there should be misconception as to the true rule applicable, that the observations made by the Madras High Court in L. G. Balakrishnan v. Commissioner of Income-tax on which reliance was placed at the Bar that if cross-transactions are independent of each other the section cannot have any application. Even if they are parts of the same transaction they would fall outside the section if they are real. But if they are nothing more than mere appearances devised to circumvent the section assiduously maintained, the department can lift the veil and declare the true nature of the transaction as being one within the section - do not correctly interpret section 16 3  a , clauses  iii  and  iv . What is material is not the unreality of the cross-transactions, not whether the appearance of reality is attempted to be maintained, but whether the transfers are part of the same transaction adopted with a view to evade the implications of the section.

holdings.text: If the two transfers are inter-connected and are parts of the same transaction in such a way that it can be said that the circuitous method has been adopted as a device to evade implications of this section, the case will fall within the section.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the section says that the assets must be those of the husband, but it does not mean that the same assets should reach the wife. It may be that the assets, in the course of being transferred, may be changed deliberately into assets of a like value of another person A chain of transfers, if not comprehended by the word indirectly, would easily defeat the object of the law which is to tax the income of the wife in the hands of the husband, if the income of the wife arises to her from assets transferred by the husband

holdings.reasoning_summary: Quoting and applying precedent from Commissioner of Income-tax v. C. M. Kothari under section 16(3)(a)(iii) defining indirect transfers via interconnected chain transactions without technical consideration if evading tax

holdings.text: In C. M. Kotharis case the court was interpreting section 16 3  a  iii , but the same considerations are relevant in the application of section 16 3  a  iv .

anchor.surface_text: the court was interpreting section 16 3  a  iii , but the same considerations are relevant in the application of section 16 3  a  iv . The Tribunal merely observed that the two transactions were mutually prompted and each of the gifts provided for the consideration of the other and did not attempt an examination of the evidence in the light of the true test.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogous application of tests from section 16(3)(a)(iii) to section 16(3)(a)(iv) as both target evasion via indirect transfers to relatives

holdings.text: We are, in the circumstances, unable to sustain the answer recorded by the High Court on the second question.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, in disagreeing with the Tribunal, also did not consider all the material evidence in the light of the test suggested by this court. We are, in the circumstances, unable to sustain the answer recorded by the High Court on the second question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal's cryptic findings and High Court's failure to apply correct interconnection test or review all evidence like family relation, simultaneity, residence, lack of explanation

holdings.text: the observations made by the Madras High Court in L. G. Balakrishnan v. Commissioner of Income-tax ... do not correctly interpret section 16 3  a , clauses  iii  and  iv . What is material is not the unreality of the cross-transactions, not whether the appearance of reality is attempted to be maintained, but whether the transfers are part of the same transaction adopted with a view to evade the implications of the section.

anchor.surface_text: We may observe, lest there should be misconception as to the true rule applicable, that the observations made by the Madras High Court in L. G. Balakrishnan v. Commissioner of Income-tax on which reliance was placed at the Bar that if cross-transactions are independent of each other the section cannot have any application. Even if they are parts of the same transaction they would fall outside the section if they are real.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects focus on sham vs real transactions; emphasizes interconnection and evasion intent over veil piercing for reality

holdings.text: We allow this appeal. We direct that the case be remanded with the direction that the High Court do call upon the Tribunal to submit a statement of the case under section 66 4  of the Indian Income-tax Act in the light of the tests expounded by this court in Commissioner of Income-tax v. C. M. Kothari and that the High Court do proceed to dispose of the reference in the light of the statement of the case and such supplementary statement of the case as the Tribunal may make.

anchor.surface_text: We allow this appeal. We direct that the case be remanded with the direction that the High Court do call upon the Tribunal to submit a statement of the case under section 66 4  of the Indian Income-tax Act in the light of the tests expounded by this court in Commissioner of Income-tax v. C. M. Kothari

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court and Tribunal required to apply correct legal tests from Kothari to facts via supplementary statement

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the section says that the assets must be those of the husband, but it does not mean that the same assets should reach the wife. It may be that the assets, in the course of being transferred, may be changed deliberately into assets of a like value of another person A chain of transfers, if not comprehended by the word indirectly, would easily defeat the object of the law which is to tax the income of the wife in the hands of the husband, if the income of the wife arises to her from assets transferred by the husband
